title: Did Mythbusters do actual science or did they just 'blow **** up'? - Quora

response.answer_text: I’ve long maintained that Mythbusters is the best science programme ever made. Yes, it’s entertainment and yes, they did have a bit of an obsession with guns and explosions that got a bit tiresome to me. But they captured the core essence of science, which is: “I think this is true. Is it true?”. The show revolves around the basic principle that you don’t have to be happy with speculation, you can actually go out there and find things out using careful experiments. What’s more, they make that very process seem thrilling. I wouldn’t doubt that more people have become scientists by watching the show than a hundred more serious documentaries. Also, in reference to a number of responses that mention peer review, I’d argue Mythbusters does have a process of peer review, because of their extremely active engagement with their audience, especially the episodes where they review criticisms of earlier experiments and re-do them. That’s exactly what peer review is about: you openly publish your hypothesis, your method and your results, and anyone is free to examine it and see if they agree with you, or to try the same experiment themselves.

Mythbusters followed the scientific method, even if they were not always clear about what they were doing and how they were doing it. That method is the hallmark of science. They formed a hypothesis. They conceived of an experiment to test that hypothesis. The experiment included controls, to demonstrate that the effect was real and made a difference. They documented their results. What they did not do (or more frequently, not show) was the boring parts: setting up experiments can be hard. Getting the experiment to produce any result is frequently challenging. And they did not show what we call ‘rigor’: the care to be certain that nothing else was affecting the results, plus the precision to demonstrate the quantitative errors in their results. So, bottom line, what they did was science. It was entertaining, it was informative, and it was grossly sloppy. Not a bad tradeoff.

They did real science, and then they blew it up. Of course, the “science” was constrained by budget and the need to do an entertaining TV show. But the basic elements were all there. They had a hypothesis (or YouTube video), they attempted to test it. They usually tested it several times, but only the most visually entertaining results actually made it from the clipping room. They rarely, if ever, did proper statistical analysis, but if they had done, and gone on to show it, the show would be remembered for its ability to induce sleep in audiences. Nothing they did would be accepted for publication in a scientific journal, of course, but that wasn’t the level they were aiming for: they were aiming for visually entertaining, but definitely bona fide, evidence by using the bare bones of the scientific method. And absolutely, often they didn’t need to do it very thoroughly. They simply asked the question “is this possible”, and once they had done it (and documented it properly), the answer was known to be “yes”; once was enough to demonstrate it beyond the anecdotal evidence of possibly doctored YouTube videos. And, of course, some of the best episodes were more of engineering. The Desert Island Duct Tape episode wasn’t so much science as… well, duct tape. And if they felt it wasn’t exciting enough, they just applied some C4.

The science in Mythbusters was often of poor quality. Most of this was related to inadequate controls. For instance, in one episode, they asked the question, “which is better for fighting zombies, a gun or an axe?” When they did the comparison, only Jamie used the gun and only Adam used the axe. The problem with this experimental set up is that the two of them differ in their skills and athletic abilities. Now I’ve watched a lot of Mythbusters and I can tell you that even though he’s tubbier, Adam is actually the more athletic of the two. So the two results are not comparable. The proper way to conduct this experiment would be to have both of them try both weapons and then average the results.

Yes! Fun fact: Adam Savage and Jamie Hyneman co-authored two actual, real-world, real published-in-scientific-journals papers. Making a point: wood- versus stone-tipped projectiles | Antiquity | Cambridge Core and Investigation of the Mechanism of the Diet Soda Geyser Reaction Wait! That last one can’t be real! Actually, that whole reaction between Mentos and Diet Soda is kind of a scientific oddity, and there still isn’t a satisfying answer about how it works. So if you’re looking for a fun research paper… there you go. Now, two papers over the course of a 20 year career isn’t exactly prolific, but hey, that’s not so bad for two guys who don’t have PhDs. If your next complaint is that they were just screwing around and weren’t actually trying to publish anything, tell that to the guys who won the Nobel Prize in physics for trying to eliminate static in their microwave antennae: Cosmic Anniversary: 'Big Bang Echo' Discovered 50 Years Ago Today.

They were more scientific than the average person. But there were some rather glaring errors in their method that they failed on (and sometimes even admitted). The main one that got my goat was changing more than one variable at a time. (This can be done scientifically, but you need to have a fairly complex methodology that you can’t easily explain to the audience, and they didn’t do) So the one where they tested whether it was more fuel efficient to use AC or wind down the window, they changed the speed they tested at between the tests, and screwed the results. They later retested after admitting the error. Another one was ‘Tree catapult’, where they tested successfully in small scale, but chopped off the most useful (springy) part of the tree in large scale. It might not have changed the result, but by doing this, the results recorded are worthless.

I've caused one explosion and seen more 5ft flames than the general public will ever see. No one has never accused me of not doing real science. Pretty much any popular science programme you see on tv is not scientific. The “experiments” that they perform are never good enough for the definitive answers they claim to show. Even when they use caveats, they don't tell you that those caveats are so important that it invalidates their conclusions. That is not to say that they are useless. Far from it. These tv programmes do incredible work as science outreach mechanisms, getting children excited about science and educating science. Both of those aspects are essential for society. The experiments just aren't scientific, that is all.

They absolutely did science. They took a hypothesis (typically a purported myth), set up a controlled experiment, tested the hypothesis, and formed a conclusion. What they did is the very essence of science. The fun part about Mythbusters is that most of their science explicitly involved blowing shit up! There is no rule saying that science cannot involve blowing shit up.

Their basic premise of forming reasonably rigorous hypotheses and testing them experimentally is, in essence reasonably scientific. Obviously they are constrained by practicalities of the format and the need to create entertainment and so often their experiment lack which you might call full scientific rigour but generally not to a ridiculous degree. The sort of things they do are certainly not too bad when considered as an initial attempt to determine whether an ideas has any merit or not as opposed to thoroughly studying it, and to be fair they tend to be quite good at examining and pointing out the limitations of their tests. I think they are also very good in terms of communicating that ‘common sense’ isn’t always a good way to come to conclusions and that the scientific method is an effective way of testing ideas and achieving useful results. I many ways though what they do is more like engineering and technology than ‘pure’ science.

They do actual science, in the form of demonstration. Usually it’s a fairly distructive form, and thus things are just ‘blown up’. None of it is what you call cutting-edge research. It is more to dispel common notions or myths. That’s why the show is mythbusters. I remember they made an icecream teapot on one of their shows. Pretty fancy stuff of a quick brew, but they showed how they launch rockets without destroying the launch-pad.

Yes, and they even messed up some of their experiments. Archimedes’ mirror solution for sinking ships is a fine example. They messed it up with umpteen flat mirrors trying to focus light on a boat. I wrote them and told them to use ONE mirror with a curved surface just like the shields that were used. Lo and behold it worked. Now there are videos made on how.

Mythbusters are doing science demonstrations. They show the findings of actual science in an approachable way. They are, however, not grossly unscientific. Actual science works differently. In actual science you do research/develop a hypothesis publish your findings and then other scientists review your work and you discuss it with them.

Yup, they did basic science. But it was more like “proof of concept” work, than what typically goes into research. It was primarily an entertainment show, that wiped a little science onto the audience. And yes, they did like making explosions too. Or as the comic XKCD succinctly put it - xkcd: Unscientific
What makes you think it’s an either/or? Blowing shit up is science if blowing it up answers pertinent questions and you record the results.
To quote Adam Savage, “The difference between science and just screwing around is taking notes.”

Mythbusters is sort of science like, in that they are experimentally investigating an hypothesis (the myth of the week). Where it fails to be science in that there is no follow up, no statistical analysis, no peer review. These might be called “science demonstrations”.

The sometimes did science, and sometimes they just blew s#$% up. Most of the time, their science was pretty crummy, but almost always entertaining. Also, as other have pointed out, blowing stuff up is not inconsistent with science. And blowing stuff up is always very fun and often entertaining.
When the program first started they were doing demonstrations of this or that on more or less scientific principles. After a few years it degenerated into explosions and gun play. I stopped watching.

MythBusters are based on “reproducible” scientific concepts. They are not science fiction. I have not watched them. What I have stated here is my “inference” based on the Wikipedia article and my “overall wisdom/stupidity”.
i would like to quote them here “remember kids, it is-int messing about as long as you write it down” and most of the math and conclusions they come to do use real world science,n stuff
Well, they generated hypotheses and tested them. Sounds like science to me. Science is messing around and writing down what happens… So they blew stuff up for science!
XKCD answered this one about as well as anyone could. xkcd: Unscientific
According to them the difference between science and just blowing stuff up is taking notes. They took notes so they were doing science
It was an entertainment show with a scientific bent. Tremendously appealing and useful to inspire people to look into science. However, it did no science as such.
